    public abstract class BaseStringConverter<Value>
extends BaseConverter<java.lang.String,​Value>
implements StringConverter<Value>
    Base class for conversions to and from String objects.

    Converting to and from Strings

    It would be more elegant for this class to implement the Converter interface twice, but due to type erasure in Java, this class cannot implement both Converter<String, Value> and Converter<Value, String>, so instead it implements Converter<String, Value>, which is the most common case and then it provides a separate method, toString(Object) which converts from Value to String. In the event that a Converter<Value, String> is required, the toStringConverter() method can be called to retrieve that converter.

    Subclasses implement conversion by overriding onConvertToObject(String). If no implementation is given for onConvertToString(Object), a default implementation is provided which simply converts the object to a String by calling Object.toString().

    Empty Strings

    Just as BaseConverter has an option to allow or disallow null values, BaseStringConverter has an option to allow or disallow empty strings. An empty string null, zero length or contains nothing but whitespace. The method allowEmpty(boolean) can be used to allow empty values (which are not allowed by default), and allowsEmpty() will return true if the converter allows empty strings.

    Thread Safety

    Note: String converters in general are thread-safe as the base classes do not have mutable state, but some specific string converters implementations may have mutable state, for example, Java formatter objects. Such converters will not be thread-safe.

    Author:
    jonathanl (shibo)
    See Also:
    BaseConverter, StringConverter
